Research Centre for Chemical Process Simulation and Intensification, School of Chemical Engineering, Xiangtan University, Xiangtan 411105, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Supported vanadium-phosphorus oxide (VPO) bilayer composite catalysts were prepared using oxygen storage compounds (CeO2, ZrO2, TiO2, and other forms) as catalyst supports, and applied to the aldol condensation of acetic acid and formaldehyde to produce acrylic acid. The active oxygen species on the crystal surface of rod-shaped CeO2 (VPO/CeO2-r) catalyst loaded with VPO effectively suppress catalyst carbon deposition and deactivation. CeO2-r had good oxygen storage and oxygen transfer capabilities. The surface microstructure, catalytic performance, and oxygen vacancies were characterized by SEM, XRD, FI-IR, BET, TG, and EPR methods. The influence of catalytic support and reaction conditions was interrelated in an oxygen-containing atmosphere. RSM experimental design was performed and fitted to the kinetic. Under the optimal reaction conditions, using 40 % VPO/CeO2-r, O2 flow rate of 6 mL/min, the yield of acrylic acid was 72.6 %, and there was no carbon deposition or deactivation after the operation cycle. Graphical Abstract Active oxygen species regulate aldol condensation reaction on VPO/CeO2-r catalyst with double-layer composite structure Keywords Aldol condensation Oxygen species Bilayer structure Oxygen vacancy Carbon deposition Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Acrylic acid, as an important chemical monomer and raw material for organic synthesis, was widely used in synthetic resins, synthetic fibers, adhesives, building materials, coatings, paints and other important production areas [1–3]. The traditional acrylic acid preparation method used two-step propylene oxidation, propylene oxidation to generate acrolein and then oxidized to generate acrylic acid [4,5]. Propylene as a petroleum-based raw material, with the dwindling petroleum resources the price of propylene was on the rise. Increased cost of raw materials [6]. Compared with the traditional two-step oxidation method, the one-step aldol condensation reaction had the advantages of high yield of target products, easy separation, and few by-products [7–9]. Therefore, from a comprehensive perspective of economy and green chemistry, the coal based route for the condensation of acetic acid and formaldehyde to produce acrylic acid was receiving increasing attention. Choosing efficient and stable catalysts played an important role in improving the yield and selectivity of acrylic acid. Acidic catalysts were reported to have good catalytic effects and wide applications in aldol condensation reactions [10,11]. In the catalytic process, formaldehyde was protonated at the acidic site to form a carbon-positive ion, which was used to obtain β-hydroxypropionic acid via a nucleophilic addition reaction with another active protonated carbonyl compound using the nucleophilicity of α-C. The carbonyl compound was then rapidly dehydrated under the action of protons to produce the more stable α-β-unsaturated carbonyl compound [12,13]. Zuo et al. [14] proposed the catalytic mechanism of P-modified ZSM-5 catalyst for the condensation reaction of hydroxyhydroxyaldehydes, in which the Lewis acid site (L-acid) increased the carbonyl polarity of methyl acetate, and the activation of formaldehyde and the formation of ester-enol forms were related to the Brownsted acid site (B-acid). As a typical acidic catalyst, the VPO catalyst contained VOPO4(V5 +) and (VO)2P2O7(V4+) in the catalyst could be interconverted with each other effectively improving the catalytic ability. Feng et al. [15] efficiently converted acetic acid (methyl acetate) and formaldehyde to acrylic acid (methyl acrylate) by vanadium oxide (VPO) catalysts prepared from polyethylene glycol (PEG) additives, and the efficient catalytic effect was closely related to the number of VOPO4 entities, the ratio of VOPO4/(VO)2P2O7, the composition of the feedstocks, and the concentration of oxygen in the support. Yang et al. [16] obtained the optimum specific surface area of the VPO catalyst by controlling the calcination temperature; sufficient air and high temperature favored the combustion of carbon accumulated on the catalyst surface and the oxidation of V4+ to V5+. Faizan et al. [17] showed that each structure in the VPO complex had different phase compositions and unique surface morphology, including valence, lattice oxygen, acidity, and other physicochemical properties. Larger specific surface area and higher V4+ concentration favored higher conversion and selectivity of acrylic acid. In fresh, used and renewed catalysts, the ratio of different V atoms might be a key factor affecting catalyst deactivation. Therefore, the factors affecting the catalytic performance of VPO catalysts included the physical phase of the catalyst itself, morphology, surface P/V ratio, V oxidation state, and surface acid-base active sites. The process of aldol condensation reaction to generate acrylic acid was accompanied by the production of water, water would exacerbate the adsorption of formaldehyde in the acidic site, a large number of formaldehyde was activated easily with polyaromatic alkylation, easy to form the phenomenon of carbon accumulation [18]. Carbon deposits generated during the reaction covered the acid-base active sites on the catalyst surface, clogging the catalyst pores as well as affecting the catalytic activity. VOPO4(V5+) in VPO was reduced to (VO)2P2O7(V4+), resulting in the deactivation of the catalyst [19,20]. Ai et al. [21] reported that the activity and selectivity of the target products of aldol condensation reactions were determined by the balance between acid and base. Strong basicity promoted the formation of CO2 and methanol, while the addition of too much acidic oxides inhibited the catalyst activity. The advantages in VPO catalysts were reflected in excellent dehydrogenation and catalytic properties. The selectivity was higher but suffered from the problem of easy carbon accumulation [22–25]. The higher catalytic activity was due to the electron transfer properties and the presence of abundant oxygen species in the VPO crystals [26]. The slow rate of lattice oxygen diffusion in VPO catalysts was the main reason for the unsustainable increase in activity and carbon buildup [27–29]. At the same time, the α-H substance contained on the carboxyl carbonyl α-C in acetic acid, due to the strong electron-absorbing effect of the carbonyl group, makes the α-H exists in a certain acidity, which belongs to the active hydrogen. Using dehydrogenation catalyst to make α-H removal to form active C-center, and then and formaldehyde nucleophilic addition reaction dehydration to produce acrylic acid [30,31]. The α-H activation was the key step in the reaction control. Therefore, how to improve the diffusion rate of lattice oxygen in VPO, activate α-H to promote the reaction, and inhibit the carbon accumulation phenomenon were the key issues to be addressed. According to previous research, VPO was loaded onto a corresponding carrier to enhance catalytic activity through interaction between the support and catalyst [32–34]. Therefore, oxygen storage compounds could be chosen as supports for VPO catalysts. The abundant oxygen vacancies, unique crystal structure, and high surface oxygen migration rate in oxygen storage compounds could enhance the activity and stability of catalysts and suppressed carbon deposition [35,36]. Cerium dioxide(CeO2), as an important rare-earth metal oxide with excellent controllable oxygen storage-exchange capacity and abundant surface oxygen species, was widely used as a catalyst or support material for non-homogeneous redox reactions and acid-base catalyzed reactions [37–39]. For example, reactions such as catalytic oxidation of volatile organic compounds [40], water gas shift reaction [41], and oxidation esterification of aldehydes [42]. The storage and transformation properties of oxygen species in CeO2 were caused by the abundance of oxygen vacancies in the crystal cells and the rapid reversible reduction of the Ce4+ crystalline phase to the Ce3+ crystalline phase [43]. CeO2 had a high oxygen mobility and a certain ability to store/release and rapidly transferred oxygen in the crystal lattice during the reaction process [44]. Therefore, the lattice oxygen diffusion rate was enhanced by modulating the number of crystal defects in the VPO microstructure by doping or loading, the Cross-aldol condensation reaction was enhanced by employing the modulation of reactive oxygen species, and the carbon-accumulation effect during the reaction process was effectively reduced by loading VPO on CeO2. In this work, different oxygen storage oxides were selected as catalytic supports to evaluate the performance of VPO catalysts in a fixed-bed catalyst evaluation device. Different oxygen storage oxides (TiO2, V2O5, CeO2, ZrO2, Al2O3) were selected as catalyst supports. Different contents of VPO were loaded on CeO2 with high oxygen storage capacity, and the catalytic performance and carbon deposition inhibition of the catalysts were investigated under oxygenated atmosphere. The effects of VPO/CeO2 catalysts on the yield and selectivity of acrylic acid under different preparation and reaction conditions were analyzed by XRD, SEM, BET, FT-IR, TG and EPR. The effect of different reaction conditions on the yield of acrylic acid was investigated by response surface analysis. The kinetics of aldol condensation reaction was analyzed, and the activation energy results of kinetic fitting further explained the mechanism of aldol condensation reaction. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals Vanadium pentoxide (≥99.0 %), benzyl alcohol (≥99.0 %), isobutyl alcohol (≥99.0 %), and polyethylene glycol 6000 (≥99.0 %) were purchased from the official website of National Drug Reagent. Phosphoric acid (≥85.0 %), acetic acid (≥99.0 %), and paraformaldehyde (≥99.0 %) were purchased from McLean Reagent. Deionized water was used to configure the above solutions, and all reagents were analytically pure. 2.2 Synthesis of CeO2 CeO2 nanoparticles were prepared using previous studies [45]. The blocky CeO2 nanoparticles were prepared by conventional precipitation method. Firstly, a certain amount of Ce(NO3)3⋅6 H2O was weighed and dissolved in deionized water, and then a NaOH/Na2CO3 solution of 0.8 mol/L NaOH and 0.25 mol/L Na2CO3 was configured, and dripped into cerium nitrate solution with vigorous stirring to control the pH of 10. After complete dripping, the solution was aged at room temperature for 2 h, and then filtered and washed with deionized water to neutrality. The CeO2 nanoparticles were dried in an oven at 80°C for 12 h and calcined in a muffle furnace at 500°C for 4 h at 10 °C/min to obtain CeO2 nanoparticles, recorded as CeO2-p. CeO2 nanorods and nanocubes were prepared using the preparation steps in previous studies. 0.05 mol/L Ce(NO3)3⋅6 H2O solution was added drop by drop into a vigorously stirred 6 mol/L NaOH solution, mixed well, and then stirred for 30 min. The mixed solution was transferred to a stainless steel hydrothermal synthesis reactor. The hydrothermal treatment was carried out at 100 °C and 180 °C for 24 h. Then it was filtered and washed with deionized water to neutral. It was dried in an oven at 80 °C for 12 h and calcined in a muffle furnace at 400 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C/min for 3 h. CeO2 nanorods and CeO2 nanocubes were obtained respectively, denoted as CeO2-r and CeO2-c. 2.3 Catalyst preparation The precursor VOHPO4·0.5 H2O was prepared by the organic solvent method. firstly, V2O5 isobutanol and benzyl alcohol were added into a three-necked flask in a certain ratio, and refluxed with mixing and stirring in an oil bath at 140 K for 6 h. As the temperature was lowered, then a certain amount of PEG 6000 was added with CeO2 support. The temperature was raised to 413 K and then refluxed for 1 h. A certain amount of phosphoric acid solution was added drop by drop. After refluxing for another 6 h, the catalyst was filtered and washed with ethanol, dried in an oven at 120°C for 12 h, and roasted at 350°C for 5 h in a muffle furnace at a rate of 10 °C/min to obtain the VPO/CeO2 catalyst. 2.4 Catalyst characterization Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis: The morphology and thickness of the materials were determined using a field-emission environmental scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, S-4800, Hitachi) at an accelerating voltage of 20.00 kV. The distribution of elements was analyzed by EDS spectroscopy. X-ray diffraction (XRD): The measuring instrument was a WJGS-009 X-ray diffractometer D8 ADVANCE with a Cu Ka X-ray radiation source for qualitative and quantitative analysis of crystalline material phases, crystallinity analysis, and grain size analysis at an angle of 2θ = 5–80°. Infrared analysis (FT-IR): Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer Nicolet5700 was used to characterize the functional group composition and crystal structure of the catalysts, and a small amount of potassium bromide was mixed and ground with the catalysts, and test was carried out after pressing the tablets, with a spectral test range of 4000–400 cm−1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG): The instrument was used for thermogravimetric analysis with TG-DTA92. The catalysts to be tested were loaded into alumina crucibles and heated up to 800 ℃ at a rate of 10 ℃/min in an air atmosphere. Physical adsorption (BET): The instrument used for physical adsorption characterization was ASAP2460 Physical Adsorption Meter. The catalysts were degassed at 200 ℃ for 6 h prior to the characterization, and the catalysts were characterized by adsorption/desorption isotherms in the presence of liquid nitrogen. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS): The instrument model was Thermo ESCALAB 250XI electron spectrometer with vacuum less than 2.0 × 10−7 mbar. The elemental composition, chemical state, and corresponding valence content of the catalysts were analyzed by XPS. The binding energies of the elements were calibrated at C1s = 284.8 eV by split-peak fitting. Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR): The test instrument was a Bruker EMXplus, which utilizes a microwave pulse system that causes the catalyst to absorb microwave radiation at a specific frequency. The EPR result signal was used to analyze the nature of the oxygen vacancies in the catalyst. 2.5 Catalytic activity measurements The catalyst evaluation process was carried out using a fixed bed evaluation device. The reaction tube had an inner diameter of 8 mm, an outer diameter of 10 mm, and a length of 30 cm. catalyst pressing was performed using a powder press to screen the catalyst between 20 and 40 mesh. The catalyst volume during reaction use was 5 mL, and both ends were filled with quartz cotton so that the catalyst was located in the middle position of the reaction tube. Acetic acid and paraformaldehyde were configured into a feedstock solution according to a certain molar ratio, and the feedstock was passed into the reaction device through an advection pump. A certain flow rate of air was passed into the reaction device through an air generator, and the carrier gas and the reacted raw material liquid are passed through the upper end of the reaction tube. The temperature was controlled by a temperature control device, and after reaching the reaction temperature, samples were taken at intervals for chromatographic analysis. The sample analysis instrument was Shimadzu GC7890 gas chromatograph for quantitative analysis, and the capillary column was PONA (50 m×10 m). The capillary column was PONA (50 m×0.20 mm×0.5μm). The internal standard was isopropanol, and different concentrations of standard solutions were configured. The peak areas of the components to be measured and the internal standard were determined, and the correction factor was calculated by the formula of internal standard method for quantification, and the standard curve of the substance was plotted(Figure S1 and Table S1). The formula for the quantification of the internal standard was calculated as follows: (1) f i = A s × m i A i × m s Where,f i was the relative correction factor, A s , A i was the peak area of the internal standard and the material to be measured, m s , m i was the mass of the internal standard and the material to be measured. The formulae for HCHO conversion ( X HCHO ), AA selectivity ( S AA ) and yield ( Y AA ) were calculated as follows: (2) X HCHO = n initial HCHO − n residual HCHO n initial HCHO (3) S AA = n residual AA n initial HCHO − n residual AA (4) Y AA = X HCHO × S AA 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD analysis The XRD spectra of different forms of CeO2 were shown in Fig. 1A. CeO2 was a rare earth oxide with fluorite structure. The different forms of CeO2 had strong diffraction peaks at 28.5°, 33.0°, 47.4° and 56.3°, which corresponded to the (111), (200), (220) and (311) crystal planes of CeO2, respectively. There were no other impurity peaks in the figure, indicating that the synthesized was pure CeO2 phase. Observation of the diffraction peaks at different angles showed that the full width of half peak (FWHM) of CeO2-r was wider than that of CeO2-p and CeO2-c, which indicated that CeO2-r had the smallest crystallite size and the cubic sample, CeO2-c had the largest crystallite size [46]. The hydrothermal temperatures of CeO2-c and CeO2-r were different during the preparation process, and the crystals crystallized during the hydrothermal process when the temperature was 180 °C. The crystallization process was more intense and easier to form the cubic sample. The broadening of the diffraction peaks of CeO2-r also indicated the nanocrystalline nature of the substance, which was a substable structure. The XRD spectra of VPO/CeO2 at different calcination temperatures (350, 400, 450, 500, 550 °C) were shown in Fig. 1B. At 2θ= 18.1° was the typical characteristic peak of VOPO4 (PDF#47–0950), which corresponds to the (031) crystal face. At 2θ= 21.5° was the characteristic peak of (VO)2P2O7(PDF#41–0697), corresponding to the (020) crystal face. At calcination temperature of 350°C, the diffraction peaks were not significant, indicating a low number of crystals on the VPO surface. As the calcination temperature increases, the characteristic peaks of VOPO4 and (VO)2P2O7 became obvious. It indicated that the number of VPO oxides in the catalyst increased at higher calcination temperatures, and the presence of the characteristic peaks could be clearly detected. It suggested that larger particles of the oxide phase were also formed. When the calcination temperature was too high, the active phases (VO)2P2O7 and VOPO4 would be transformed. The V5+ content would be increased accordingly, leading to the decrease of active sites, which would affect the catalytic activity and the generation of target products. Suitable V4+/V5+ in VPO catalysts could better improve the catalytic performance. 3.2 TEM analysis The TEM images of CeO2 with different morphologies were shown in Fig. 2. The synthesized and prepared CeO2 nanoparticles had rod, cubic and massive structures and were essentially single crystals. For the rod-like structure CeO2-r (Fig. 2A,B), the growth was along the [110] direction. The lattice stripes shown were (110) and (111), and the lattice spacing was 0.31 nm and 0.19 nm, respectively. The main exposed crystal surfaces of CeO2-r were (110) and (111), and the interface sites were more susceptible to the formation of oxygen vacancies. The cube-like CeO2-c structure shown in Fig. 2C,D was well-defined with a smooth surface showing clear (100) lattice stripes with a lattice spacing of 0.27 nm. The cube was surrounded by six orientations mainly exposing the (100) lattice surface. The conventional bulk structure of CeO2-p was shown in Fig. 2E,F with the major crystalline facet of (111) and lattice spacing of 0.31 nm. It indicated that different morphologies exposed different crystallographic surfaces, and that the differences in the crystallographic structure affected the catalytic performance of the catalysts [38]. The oxygen storage capacity of CeO2 was also related to the concentration of oxygen vacancies [46].CeO2 could carry out redox reactions between Ce3+ and Ce4+ with good oxygen adsorption/desorption capacity. Therefore, CeO2 had corresponding active sites and catalytic ability, which contributed to the activation and dispersion of the VPO catalyst on the support. 3.3 CeO2 oxygen vacancy analysis The oxygen vacancies of CeO2 with different morphologies were tested by EPR characterization as shown in Fig. 3 below. The position of the resonance signal of CeO2 with different shapes was g= 2.003, which indicated that CeO2 had obvious oxygen vacancies. The peak response signal strengths of CeO2 with different morphologies could be obtained from the figure. According to the strength of the peaks, CeO2-r＞CeO2-c＞CeO2-p, indicating that different exposed crystal surfaces had an important effect on the oxygen vacancies. The concentration of oxygen vacancies was different because of the different exposed crystal surfaces, as shown in Table 1. It was found that oxygen vacancies played an important role in catalytic oxidation. The density of oxygen vacancies in CeO2 varies among different crystal forms. The highest oxygen vacancy density of CeO2-r was 20.8, while CeO2-c and CeO2-p were 20.0 and 18.0, respectively [43]. CeO2-r had the highest concentration and quantity of oxygen vacancies, as well as a higher surface oxygen migration rate. The density and quantity of oxygen vacancies were directly proportional to the number of Ce3+ sites. A lower formation energy of oxygen vacancies could generate a higher number and concentration of oxygen vacancies [47]. Therefore, CeO2-r had abundant oxygen vacancies and higher catalytic and reducing capacity compared with CeO2-c and CeO2-p. It indicated that CeO2-r had a higher ability to store/release oxygen. The presence of oxygen vacancies facilitated the dispersion of the loaded VPO catalyst on the ceria-based support and enhanced the role of active oxygen in the catalytic process. 3.4 SEM analysis The SEM of 40 % VPO/CeO2 catalysts were shown below in Fig. 4. As shown in Fig. 4A-C, the morphology of CeO2 was in the form of blocks, cubes and rods, and the morphology of VPO catalysts was in the form of rosettes. The VPO catalysts were uniformly loaded on CeO2. The precursors of VPO crystallized on the surface of CeO2 particles, and the loading process was carried out in-situ. After calcination and activation, the loaded catalyst was finally obtained. The scanning electron microscopy characterization of CeO2-r was shown in Fig. 4D, indicating a pronounced rod structure and good crystallinity of the crystals. To further investigate the dispersion degree of the VPO catalyst on the CeO2 surface, the EDS analysis resulted for the 40 % VPO/CeO2-r catalyst was shown in Fig. 4E-H below. In which V, P, and O elements were uniformly dispersed on the carrier surface. This indicated that there was a strong interaction between CeO2 and VPO, and the dispersion between the catalyst and the carrier was good. By adjusting the structure and morphology of CeO2, the optimal crystal structure could be obtained, thus exposing more active crystal planes. The VPO catalyst played a catalytic role in the reaction, which led to the increase of the yield of the target product acrylic acid. The 40 % VPO/CeO2-r catalysts showed excellent catalytic performance. 3.5 BET analysis The specific surface area, pore size and pore volume of VPO/CeO2 catalysts with different loading capacities were listed in Table 2. The magnitude of the specific surface area of the VPO catalyst was related to the amount of loading.The maximum specific surface area was 65.31 m2/g, pore volume was 0.367 cm3/g, and pore diameter was 22.47 nm at 40 % CeO2-r active component loading. When the loading exceeded 40 %, the increase of VPO content blocked part of the pores of the support. After multilayer coverage, the nature of the pore structure changed and the specific surface area of the catalyst decreased. Fig. 5 showed the N2 adsorption and desorption curves of catalysts with different CeO2 morphologies. From the figure, it could be seen that the curves all exhibited H3 hysteresis type. The adsorption capacity of VPO/CeO2-r was significantly higher than that of other CeO2 morphology catalysts, and the specific surface area was the largest, indicating a larger contact area with the raw material liquid during the reaction process. Simultaneously providing more catalytic active sites to improve reaction efficiency.Therefore, the catalytic activity was best when the loading of active components reached 40 %. The results showed that the specific surface area and pore size of the catalyst had a significant effect on its performance. 3.6 FT-IR analysis The FT-IR spectra of VPO/CeO2-r loaded with different active ingredients were shown in Fig. 6 below. From the figure, it can be seen that the absorption peak of the P-OH group was located at 1600 cm−1. The P-OH group was formed by the topological transformation of the precursor VOHPO4∙0.5 H2O to (VO)2P2O7. The vibrational intensity of P-OH was related to the content of (VO)2P2O7. The surface acidity of the VPO/CeO2 catalysts was closely related to that of the P-OH group. An appropriate amount of acidity was favorable to promote the reaction. When the loading of VPO/CeO2 catalyst was 40 %, the intensity of the absorption peak of P-OH group was the largest. The wave number of the hydroxyl absorption peak of hydrogen bonding was in the region of 3450 cm−1, and the intensity of the hydroxyl absorption peak increased with the increase of the loading, and the intensity of the absorption peak decreased when the loading of the active component was more than 40 %. The 40 % of VPO/CeO2 had the best acidic catalytic activity site. 3.7 TG analysis The TG curves under different conditions were shown in Fig. 7. Comparing the precursor VOHPO4∙0.5 H2O before calcination with the curve after calcination, the weight loss before 200 ℃ was the evaporation of adsorbed water molecules on the surface. The weight loss before 200°C was the evaporation of adsorbed water molecules on the surface. Since water of crystallization existed in the precursor, the weight loss process from 200 to 400°C was the process of removing the water of crystallization. The stability of the VPO catalyst was enhanced after calcination. When the VPO/CeO2-r catalyst was loaded with 40 % of VPO and the reaction temperature was 400 ℃, comparing the TG analysis curves obtained from the reaction in anaerobic and aerobic environments, it could be seen that the catalysts in anaerobic environments had serious carbon deposition. The weight of carbon deposition was significantly higher than that in the aerobic environment. After 400 ℃, the catalyst showed strong weight loss, which was the process of removing surface carbon from the catalyst. The high temperature calcination could effectively remove the carbon on the surface of the catalyst. CeO2 had significant oxygen storage/release capacity when used as a support. Oxygen storage/release through CeO2 support increased the concentration of active oxygen on the surface and accelerated the mobility of oxygen on the catalyst surface. It had an inhibitory effect on carbon deposition in the reaction, which could improve the catalytic activity, prolong the catalyst life and promote the generation of acrylic acid. 3.8 XPS analysis The V2p3/2 fitted curves of VPO/CeO2-r catalysts at different calcination temperatures (350, 400, 450, and 500°C) were analyzed by XPS as shown in Fig. 8. The binding energy positions of V4+ and V5+ were approximately at 516.6 eV and 517.7 eV. Deconvolution analysis of V2p3/2 was performed and the proportions of the active phases (VO)2P2O7 (V4+) and VOPO4 (V5+) were roughly analyzed from the plots. The results are shown in Table 3. The standard charge of C1s of 248.8ev was used for the calibration due to the error in the charge calibration of the catalyst. V4+ and V5+ were present on the catalyst surface at different calcination temperatures. In the XRD analysis, the characteristic V4+ peaks were not obvious at lower calcination temperatures, indicating that the (VO)2P2O7 phase exists mostly in amorphous form in the VPO catalyst. At the calcination temperature of 400 ℃, the active components of the catalyst were (VO)2P2O7 and VOPO4, and the maximum ratio of the two was 0.94. When the calcination temperature was increased from 400 ℃ to 500 ℃, the ratio of I V 4 + / I V 5 + gradually decreased from 0.94 to 0.65, indicating that there was a redox cycle between the active components, and some of the V4+ was oxidized to V5+ at a higher calcination temperature. The calcination temperature affects the ratio of V4+ and V5+ in the catalyst, which in turn affects the activity and catalytic performance of the catalyst. 4 Catalyst performance evaluation 4.1 Effect of different supports Acetic acid and formaldehyde under the action of an efficient catalyst undergo a hydroxyl aldehyde condensation reaction to produce acrylic acid in one step, in order to improve the yield of acrylic acid, specific catalysts were needed. Acid base bifunctional catalysts, as a key catalyst of concern, had good applications in aldol condensation reactions. Supports played an important role in catalysts, not only affecting their catalytic activity, but also enhancing their thermal stability, mechanical properties, and structural stability. The VPO catalysts were uniformly dispersed and loaded on CeO2, Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2, and ZrO2, respectively. The catalytic activity of VPO catalysts with different supports was shown below in Fig. 9A. From the figure, it could be seen that the VPO/CeO2 catalyst had the best reactivity, and the yield of acrylic acid could reach 72.6 %, which was higher than that of the VPO/Al2O3 catalyst, which was 55.28 %. The use of CeO2 as an oxygen storage support could effectively suppress the phenomenon of catalyst carbon deposition and improve catalytic activity. The catalytic activity of VPO/CeO2-r, VPO/CeO2-c, and VPO/CeO2-p using CeO2 with different morphologies as supports was shown in Fig. 9B. From the reaction results, it could be seen that the catalytic effect of VPO/CeO2-r was significantly higher than that of other morphologies of CeO2. Different crystal structures of CeO2 were exposed to different crystal faces, CeO2-r was exposed to (110) and (111). The formation energy of Ov (surface oxygen vacancy) on different crystal planes varies. According to DFT calculations, the order of the Ov formation energy of CeO2 was (110)< (100)< (111) [48]. So the different crystal structures and crystal faces of the support had significant impact on the catalytic performance. CeO2-r had the ability to induce oxygen rich vacancies and had significant advantages in fast storage/release and transfer of lattice oxygen. 4.2 Effect of calcination temperature The 40 % VPO/CeO2-r catalyst was roasted at 350, 400, 450, 500 and 550 °C for 5 h. Acrylic acid was produced by hydroxyaldehydes condensation from formaldehyde under atmospheric pressure using a fixed-bed catalyst evaluation unit. The effects of different calcination temperatures on the catalyst performance at O2 flow rate of 6 mL/min, reaction temperature of 350°C, a molar ratio of HAc/HCHO of 5:1, and liquid phase vacancy velocity (LHSV) of 1.0 h−1 were shown in Fig. 10 below. It could be seen that the highest reaction yield was obtained at a calcination temperature of 400 °C. The reaction yield of the catalysts at a calcination temperature of 400°C was also found to be the highest. As calcination temperature increased from 400 ℃ to 550 ℃, the yield of acrylic acid gradually decreased from the optimum yield of 72.6–38.5 %. XRD and XPS characterization results showed that calcination temperature affects the ratio of V4+ and V5+, the acid-base strength and the number of active sites in the catalyst, which in turn affects the catalytic activity. When the density of acidic sites was high, formaldehyde activation and intermediate conversion were favored during the reaction. The lower V5+/V4+ ratio but higher basic sites favored acetic acid activation and C-C bond formation [7,14]. According to previous studies, the calcination temperature affected the crystal structure, acid-base site density and strength, and acid site properties of the catalyst [49]. Too high a temperature affected the size and structure of the catalyst particle size, resulting in clogged pores and decreased catalytic activity. At a calcination temperature of 400°C, a higher V4+ concentration favors the conversion and selectivity of acrylic acid, indicating the optimal activity of the catalyst. 4.3 Effect of different VPO loadings The performance of VPO/CeO2-r catalysts was evaluated by different active component loadings at calcination temperature of 400 °C, O2 flow rate of 6 mL/min, reaction temperature of 350 °C, molar ratio of HAc/HCHO of 5:1, and LHSV of 1.0 h−1. The catalytic performances were shown in Fig. 11 below. The acrylic acid yield increased from 46.1 % to 72.6 % with the increase of VPO active component loading, but the yield decreased to 56.5 % with too high active component loading. The maximum yield of acetic acid reacting with formaldehyde to produce acrylic acid was 72 % at a loading of 40 %. The increase of the active component of VPO in the first stage improved the catalytic activity, but the catalytic activity was affected when the content was too much, which did not allow sufficient and effective dispersion between VPO and CeO2-r support. 4.4 Influence of reaction conditions under oxygenated atmosphere 4.4.1 Effect of different O2 flow rates The effect of O2 flow rate on the catalytic reaction performance of the catalysts was investigated at a calcination temperature of 400 °C, loading of 40 % VPO/CeO2-r catalyst, LHSV of 1.0 h−1, reaction temperature of 350 °C, and HAc/HCHO molar ratio of 5:1. The higher the air flow rate, the higher the oxygen content in a certain time. According to the proportion of O2 content in the air, the effects of different O2 flow rates on the catalytic performance of the catalysts were shown in Fig. 12 below. At low O2 concentrations, as the reaction proceeded, the acrylic acid yield was lower and the catalyst performance decreased faster, with serious carbon accumulation on the catalyst surface and reduced catalyst life. As the O2 content gradually increased, the selectivity and yield of acrylic acid also gradually increased, and the optimum yield was 72.6 % at O2 flow rate of 6 mL/min. When the O2 flow rate continued to increase to 10 mL/min, excessive oxygen concentration could cause excessive oxidation of reactants or products, resulting in a decrease in the selectivity of acrylic acid and a decrease in yield, from 72.6 % to 51.7 %. In addition, the rapid O2 flow rate drove the raw material liquid, reducing the residence time of the catalyst and preventing timely reaction, which also reduced the yield of acrylic acid. It indicated that the generation of the target product acrylic acid was favored in an oxygen environment, the oxygen had the effect of promoting the removal of α-H and anti-accumulation of carbon in the catalytic process, and the presence of lattice oxygen favored the formation of α-C anion. CeO2-r as the support has abundant oxygen vacancies and oxygen storage capacity which well inhibited the carbon accumulation on the catalyst surface, improved the catalyst activity and promoted the reaction. 4.4.2 Effect of liquid phase vacancy velocity (LHSV) The VPO/CeO2-r catalysts were evaluated at calcination temperature of 400 ℃, O2 flow rate of 6 mL/min, a reaction temperature of 350 ℃, a molar ratio of HAc/HCHO of 5:1, and a loading of 40 % of active components. During the catalyst evaluation, the mixed raw material solution of acetic acid and formaldehyde was fed through a parallel flow pump, and the effect of contact time of the feed solutions on the catalytic performance was investigated by different feed rates. The results of catalyst performance evaluation at different LHSV were shown in Fig. 13 below. When the LHSV was low, the residence time of the feed solution on the catalyst was too long. The side reactions were easy to increase, which decreased the selectivity of acrylic acid and was not favorable to improve the yield of acrylic acid. The selectivity of acrylic acid tends to stabilize with the increase of LHSV. When the liquid-air velocity was high, the contact time between the feedstock liquid and the catalyst was too short leading to insufficient reaction, resulting in a decrease in acrylic acid yield. Therefore, the highest acrylic acid yield of 72.6 % was obtained when the liquid-phase-hollow speed was 1.0 h−1. 4.4.3 Effect of different reaction temperatures The effect of different reaction temperatures on acrylic acid yield and selectivity at calcination temperature of 400°C, O2 flow rate of 6 mL/min, loading of 40 % VPO/CeO2-r catalyst, and LHSV of 1.0 h−1 was shown in Fig. 14 below. When the temperature was increased from 310 °C to 350 °C, the yield of acrylic acid gradually increased, from at 350 °C acrylic acid had an optimum yield of 72.6 %, indicating that the appropriate temperature was favorable for the generation of the target product. As the reaction temperature increased, the by-products increased and the selectivity of acrylic acid gradually decreased. The carbon buildup on the catalyst increased, covering the acid-base active sites on the surface, blocking the catalyst pores and affecting the catalytic activity resulting in the deactivation of the catalyst, causing the acrylic acid yield to decrease accordingly. When the reaction temperature was increased to 390 °C, the acrylic acid yield decreased from 72.6 % to 43.2 %. So acrylic acid had an optimum reaction temperature of 350 °C. 4.4.4 Effects of different HAc/HCHO molar ratios The effect of different feedstock-liquid molar ratios of HAc/HCHO on the catalytic performance at calcination temperature of 400 °C, loading of 40 % VPO/CeO2-r catalyst, LHSV of 1.0 h−1, and reaction temperature of 350 °C was shown in Fig. 15 below. With the increase of the molar ratio of feedstock liquid, the selectivity of acrylic acid gradually increased, and the acrylic acid yield also increased. However, when the content of acetic acid was too high, the concentration of HCHO was diluted to reduce the reaction rate, and a large amount of acetic acid would be adsorbed on the active sites of the catalyst to reduce the catalytic activity, and the yield of acrylic acid was reduced accordingly. When the HAc/HCHO molar ratio was increased from 5:1–9:1, the acrylic acid yield decreased from 72.6 % to 41.2 %, so the HAc/HCHO molar ratio of 5:1 was optimal. 4.5 Response surface methodology (RSM) analysis 4.5.1 RSM predicted model In the formation of acrylic acid from acetic acid and formaldehyde via aldol condensation reaction, suitable reaction conditions could improve the catalytic performance of the catalyst and promote the reaction. RSM was used to design experiments based on Box-Behnken design to evaluate the effects of feedstock-liquid HAc/HCHO molar ratio (X1), the reaction temperature (X2), and the air flow rate(X3) on acrylic acid yield. Air flow rates (X3) of 10, 20, 30, 40, and 50 mL/min correspond to O2 flow rates of 2, 4, 6, 8, and 10 mL/min, respectively. Due to the different reaction conditions, the acrylic acid yield changed accordingly, and the optimum conditions for generating acrylic acid yield were obtained by determining the best fitting model for each response variable. The variables were feedstock-liquid molar ratio HAc/HCHO, reaction temperature, and air flow rate, and the coding equation for acrylic acid yield under the three variables was shown by the following Eq. (5). Two levels for each variable. Coded as + 1 and −1, representing high and low values respectively, were shown in Table S2 below. The predicted values of acrylic acid yield were calculated by the fitted model and compared with the actual yield values as shown in Fig. 16 below. The correlation coefficient between predicted and actual values, R2 = 0.993, and the experimental values were distributed near the predicted values, indicating that the experimental values had a good linear correlation with the predicted values. According to the statistical analysis of the main effect and interaction effect of each variable on acrylic yield, the experimental data were analyzed using analysis of variance (ANOVA), which could verify the validity of the fitted model, and the ANOVA was shown in Table 4 below. The regression model value of P < 0.0001 indicates that the model is highly significant and the lack of fit P = 0.15 > 0.0500 indicates that it is not statistically significant. The model F value (F=11.09), indicated that the model was significant. Therefore, the model was feasible and could be analyzed to predict the acrylic acid yield. (5) Y % = 73.61 + 1.62 X 1 + 1.32 X 2 + 0.51 X 3 − 0.99 X 1 X 2 − 0.64 X 1 X 3 − 2.35 X 2 X 3 − 6.09 X 1 2 − 6.18 X 2 2 − 2.07 X 3 2 4.5.2 Response surface analysis The effect of the interaction of HAc/HCHO molar ratio and reaction temperature on acrylic acid yield at an air flow rate of 30 mL min−1 was shown in Fig. 17 below. The acrylic acid yield showed an increasing and then decreasing trend with the increase of molar ratio and reaction temperature, which indicated that the increase of reaction temperature and HAc/HCHO molar ratio was favorable for the increase of acrylic acid yield, but at too high molar ratio and reaction temperature, the acrylic acid yield was reduced accordingly because of the easy deactivation of the VPO catalyst and the increase of side reactions. The two-dimensional contour plots of the interaction between reaction temperature and HAc/HCHO molar ratio were nearly elliptical, indicating that the interaction between HAc/HCHO molar ratio and reaction temperature had a significant effect. The trend of the interaction of HAc/HCHO molar ratio and air flow rate on acrylic acid yield at a reaction temperature of 350 °C was shown in Fig. 18 below. The acrylic acid yield increased and then decreased with the increase of HAc/HCHO moles, and too high molar ratio diluted the HCHO concentration affecting the acrylic acid generation rate. When a certain air flow rate was exceeded, the acrylic acid production rate decreased accordingly, which was the same as the results of the one-factor effect. There was an interaction between the two factors of HAc/HCHO molar ratio and air flow rate. The trend of the interaction between reaction temperature and air flow rate on the yield of acrylic acid under the condition of a molar ratio of 5:1 was shown in Fig. 19. With the increase of reaction temperature and air flow rate, the yield of acrylic acid first increased and then decreased. The appropriate oxygen content fully suppressed the carbon phenomenon on the catalyst surface, but when the flow rate was too high, it was easy to cause insufficient reaction and decreased in reaction conversion rate. From the contour plot analysis, it was shown that the interaction between the HAc/HCHO molar ratio and other factors was significant. In order to verify the credibility of the fitted model, model validation experiments were conducted. By optimizing the process through RSM and predicting the optimal process conditions, the predicted and actual results were shown in Table S4. The predicted yield of acrylic acid was 73.72 % when the HAc/HCHO molar ratio (X1) was 5.05:1, the reaction temperature (X2) was 351.12 ℃, and the air flow rate (X3) was 30.2 mL/min. The optimal conditions for actual value operation were: when the HAc/HCHO molar ratio was 5:1, the reaction temperature was 350 ℃, and the air flow rate was 30 mL min−1, the yield of acrylic acid was 72.6 %, which was similar to the optimal conditions for RSM optimization process, indicating the reliability of the prediction model. 4.6 Kinetic of aldol condensation reaction In order to study the chemical reaction rate and discuss the effect of reaction conditions on the target products. Therefore, a kinetic study was carried out in a fixed-bed reaction unit using a VPO/CeO2 catalyst applied to the aldol condensation reaction to generate acrylic acid. In order to obtain accurate experimental data under kinetic conditions, the effect of internal and external diffusion should be eliminated first. The effect of external diffusion on the reaction was considered first. The effect of external diffusion on the yield of acrylic acid was investigated at a reaction temperature of 350 °C and a fixed air velocity of 0.09 mL/min during the reaction, within the range of air velocity of 0.04–0.22 mL/min(Figure S2). After analyzing the experimental results, when the liquid phase air velocity was greater than 0.09 mL/min, the yield of acrylic acid was almost unchanged, so the effect of external diffusion was negligible under this condition. At the same time, the reaction studied the effect of 10–50 mesh particle size range on the reaction(Figure S3), analyzed by experimental results, when the particle size was larger than 20 mesh, the conversion of the reaction did not change significantly, indicating that the effect of internal diffusion could be ignored. After eliminating internal and external diffusion, the kinetic study was carried out by assuming a kinetic model [50]. Thus, the kinetic equation of the aldol condensation reaction was： (6) r A = − d C A dt = k C 1 C HCHO a C HAc b − k C 2 C AA l C H 2 O m where rA denoted the chemical reaction rate. The power indices a and b were the reaction levels of the components HCHO and HAc in the forward reaction rate equation, respectively. The power indices l and m were the reaction levels of components AA and H2O, respectively, in the inverse reaction rate equation. k C 1 and k C 2 were the positive and inverse reaction rate constants expressed in terms of concentration, which were independent of the concentration of the reaction components. During the reaction, the content of acetic acid was too high (HAc:HCHO=5:1), it could be considered that the concentration remained constant, so the reverse reaction could be ignored. Therefore the above kinetic equation could be converted to: (7) r A = − d C A dt = k C 1 C HCHO a The change process of formaldehyde concentration with reaction temperature and liquid phase air velocity was investigated as the reaction proceeded at different reaction temperatures (325–355 °C) and different times (as shown in Table S3 below). At different reaction temperatures, the variation of formaldehyde concentration with reaction time t was nonlinearly fitted to obtain the fitted functional equation: (8) C A − C 0 = A 1 exp − x t 1 Derivation of both sides of the above equation yields the reaction rate under different airspeed conditions rA. Taking the logarithm of both sides of the above equation yields: (9) ln r A = lnk + a ln C HCHO According to the Arrhenius equation, the kinetic constants were independent of concentration and only related to the reaction temperature: (10) k = A e − E a RT Taking logarithms on both sides of the formula, the formula could be converted to: (11) ln k = ln A − E a RT Where Ea was the reaction activation energy and A was the prefinger factor. Therefore, the reaction kinetic parameters were fitted and calculated by the above fitting equation. According to the fitting Eq. (8), the variation process of formaldehyde concentration with time at different temperatures (325–355 °C) was obtained as shown in Fig. 20, and the curves were all in good correlation. The specific parameter values were shown in Table S5. The fitted curve of lnCHCHO-lnrA obtained from the above Eq. (9) was shown in Fig. 21. The concentration change of formaldehyde, lnCHCHO, was the x-axis and the reaction rate, ln r, was the y-axis. The fitted curve obtained had a slope of a and an intercept of lnk. The specific values were shown in Table S6. The change in activation energy Ea was independent of temperature, so the curve was fitted as shown in Fig. 22 using the reciprocal of temperature 1/T as the horizontal coordinate and the logarithm of the rate constant lnk as the horizontal coordinate. The activation energy of the reaction Ea = 45 kJ/mol and R2 = 0.991 could be obtained from the figure, indicating that the fitted kinetic equation was applicable to the aldol condensation reaction. 4.7 Catalyst life In order to investigate the stability and catalytic lifetime of the catalyst, the performance of 40 % VPO/CeO2-r catalyst was evaluated under the optimal reaction conditions (calcination temperature of 400 ℃, reaction temperature of 350 °C, oxygenated air flow rate of 30 mL/min). The catalyst yield variation with time was shown by Fig. 23. The catalyst yield showed a decreasing and then stabilizing trend with the increase of reaction time. The slight decrease in catalyst performance might be due to the carbon accumulation on the catalyst surface during the reaction process. Catalysts have the ability to store/release oxygen, and reactive oxygen species flow and convert between VPO catalysts and CeO2 supports. When reacting for 30 h the catalyst lifetime decreased to about 58 %. The catalyst was roasted again, the carbon was effectively removed, and the catalytic performance was recovered to about 68 %. The catalytic performance was basically restored. It was shown that the 40 % VPO/CeO2-r catalyst had good stability and a long catalyst life in repeated use. 5 Mechanism analysis of catalytic reaction enhanced by reactive oxygen species CeO2, as an important rare-earth metal oxide, had excellent controllable storage-discharge oxygen capacity, and could be rapidly transformed from between free oxygen, bulk oxygen species, and surface-active oxygen species. Therefore, the lattice oxygen diffusion rate could be enhanced and the hydroxyaldehyde condensation reaction could be modulated by loading VPO with CeO2 reactive oxygen species. The mechanism of reactive oxygen species modulation and catalytic Cross-aldol condensation reaction mechanism of CeO2-loaded VPO catalyst was shown in Fig. 24. Both VPO catalysts and CeO2 were surface oxygen species-rich materials. CeO2 was present in (111), (110) and (100) crystal faces, and CeO2-r with (110) and (111) could easily induce a large number of oxygen vacancies. When more highly active crystal faces are exposed, the concentration of surface active oxygen species can be increased, accelerating the mobility of oxygen species on the surface of the VPO catalyst bulk phase. The storage and conversion properties of oxygen species in CeO2 were attributed to the abundance of oxygen vacancies in the crystal cells and the rapid reversible reduction of the Ce4+ crystalline phase to the Ce3+ crystalline phase. During the reaction, both the VPO catalyst and CeO2 were surface oxygen-rich species, and the lattice oxygen diffusion rate could be enhanced by modulating the number of crystal defects in the VPO microstructure by means of loading. CeO2 with high oxygen mobility was used as a support to compensate for the low efficiency of active oxygen supply on the surface of VPO catalysts. We hypothesized that during the reaction, free oxygen was adsorbed as Ce-O bond-connected oxygen species during the crystal phase transition and rapidly transferred in the abundant oxygen vacancies, eventually forming an active surface containing abundant reactive oxygen species. As the surface oxygen species of VPO gradually deplete, the bulk oxygen species in the VPO/CeO2 composite oxide could be continuously replenished to maintain a relatively constant surface active oxygen species. VPO/CeO2, as a bilayer catalyst structure, promoted the diffusion of lattice oxygen in VPO based on the excellent oxygen storage capacity of CeO2. The controlled α-H activation reaction was realized by the abundant surface active oxygen in the VPO catalyst. The removal rate of α-H was regulated by adjusting the surface-active oxygen. It inhibited carbon deposition while improving the catalytic activity. 6 Conclusion In order to minimize the carbon buildup of the catalyst, oxygen storage compounds were chosen as supports for the VPO catalyst. This would affect the acid-base active center and chemical strength of the catalyst surface. VPO/CeO2-r oxygen storage material catalyst with a bilayer composite structure was prepared. Under the oxygen-containing atmosphere, CeO2-r had abundant oxygen vacancies and oxygen storage/release capacity. The active oxygen species on the catalyst surface effectively enhanced α-H removal. The rapid flow of lattice oxygen could effectively inhibit the formation of carbon deposits on the catalyst surface and improve the catalytic activity. When the calcination temperature was 400 °C and the O2 flow rate was 6 mL/min, the acrylic acid yield was as high as 72.6 %. This was consistent with the results predicted by the RSM model. Oxygen vacancies in the catalyst crystal structure were analyzed and kinetic activity correlation was performed. It was shown that the established reaction kinetic model was applicable to the aldol condensation reaction with an activation energy Ea of 41.79 kJ/mol. After multiple cycles of operation, there was no carbon deposition or catalyst deactivation. coredata.dc:description: Supported vanadium-phosphorus oxide (VPO) bilayer composite catalysts were prepared using oxygen storage compounds (CeO2, ZrO2, TiO2, and other forms) as catalyst supports, and applied to the aldol condensation of acetic acid and formaldehyde to produce acrylic acid. The active oxygen species on the crystal surface of rod-shaped CeO2 (VPO/CeO2-r) catalyst loaded with VPO effectively suppress catalyst carbon deposition and deactivation. CeO2-r had good oxygen storage and oxygen transfer capabilities. The surface microstructure, catalytic performance, and oxygen vacancies were characterized by SEM, XRD, FI-IR, BET, TG, and EPR methods. The influence of catalytic support and reaction conditions was interrelated in an oxygen-containing atmosphere. RSM experimental design was performed and fitted to the kinetic. Under the optimal reaction conditions, using 40 % VPO/CeO2-r, O2 flow rate of 6 mL/min, the yield of acrylic acid was 72.6 %, and there was no carbon deposition or deactivation after the operation cycle.
